elements.content: This article presents an analysis of structural transformations that occur during the crystallization of Na-1,2-bis­(tetrazol-5-yl)­ethane (H2 bte) coordination polymers from solution. The crystal structures of six new Na-bte coordination polymers were elucidated, whereby [Na­(Hbte)­(CH3OH)2] n (1), [Na2(bte)­(H2O)3] n (3), and [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)] n (5) were isolated as intermediate phases during the formation of final products [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)3] n (2), [Na2(bte)2(H2O)3] n ­·2NH4·H2O (4), and [Na2(Hbte)2­(H2O)] n (6). The intermediates were isolated from the reaction mixture within 1 or 2 days, whereas the stable phases formed after 6 days. The intermediate formation of compounds 1, 3, and 5 in the reaction mixture, which further react to form the stable compounds 2, 4, and 6, reveals the formation pathway of the final products via the intermediate phases. The coordination strain imposed by the tetrazole rings of bte linkers, bulky solvent molecule MeOH in Na coordination sphere, and hydration affinity of the Na+ ion accounts for the instability of the intermediate phases. Along with the coordination flexibility provided by the aqua linkers, the stable phases acquire additional stability due to noncovalent interactions exhibited by the coordinated and lattice solvent molecules. The thermal decomposition behaviors of the stable phases are studied by thermogravimetric and calorimetric analyses.

The crystal structures of six new Na-bte coordination polymers were elucidated, whereby [Na(Hbte)(CH3OH)2] n  (1), [Na2(bte)(H2O)3] n  (3), and [Na(Hbte)(H2O)] n  (5) were isolated as intermediate phases during the formation of final products [Na(Hbte)(H2O)3] n  (2), [Na2(bte)2(H2O)3] n ⋅2NH4⋅H2O (4), and [Na2(Hbte)2(H2O)] n  (6). The intermediates were isolated from the reaction mixture within 1 or 2 days, whereas the stable phases formed after 6 days. The intermediate formation of compounds 1, 3, and 5 in the reaction mixture, which further react to form the stable compounds 2, 4, and 6, reveals the formation pathway of the final products via the intermediate phases. The coordination strain imposed by the tetrazole rings of bte linkers, bulky solvent molecule MeOH in Na coordination sphere, and hydration affinity of the Na+ ion accounts for the instability of the intermediate phases. Along with the coordination flexibility provided by the aqua linkers, the stable phases acquire additional stability due to noncovalent interactions exhibited by the coordinated and lattice solvent molecules. The thermal decomposition behaviors of the stable phases are studied by thermogravimetric and calorimetric analyses.

elements.content: Herein, we discuss the factors affecting structural rearrangements involved in transformation of intermediate phases to stable phases during the crystallization of Na-based coordination polymers. The article highlights the role of steric hindrance around the metal coordination sphere in driving the structural changes to form more stable phases.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we discuss the factors affecting structural rearrangements involved in transformation of intermediate phases to stable phases during the crystallization of Na-based coordination polymers. The article highlights the role of steric hindrance around the metal coordination sphere in driving the structural changes to form more stable phases.

elements.content:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue

Introduction

The past few years have seen progress in elucidating the mechanisms behind the crystallization of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs). It has been demonstrated that the formation of intermediate phases during the crystallization of coordination frameworks can be influenced by both synthetic procedures and coordinative restraints. The variables affecting the identity of the final products of crystallization have been investigated and established by various experimental and theoretical methods. Factors like entropic gain, strain in metal coordination sphere, hydration, and synthetic control can greatly influence the composition of coordination polymers obtained as a result of crystallization. The phase transformations observed by exposing the crystalline material to external factors were shown to drive the transformation of intermediate phases into their more stable counterparts.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue 

Introduction

The past few years have seen progress in elucidating the mechanisms behind the crystallization of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs). It has been demonstrated that the formation of intermediate phases during the crystallization of coordination frameworks can be influenced by both synthetic procedures and coordinative restraints. The variables affecting the identity of the final products of crystallization have been investigated and established by various experimental and theoretical methods. Factors like entropic gain, strain in metal coordination sphere, hydration, and synthetic control can greatly influence the composition of coordination polymers obtained as a result of crystallization. The phase transformations observed by exposing the crystalline material to external factors were shown to drive the transformation of intermediate phases into their more stable counterparts.

elements.content: Yeung et al. addressed the influence of thermodynamic and kinetic parameters during the crystallization of MOFs in a broader way by highlighting the role of synthetic parameters. Temperature plays an important role in thermodynamic control of whether the formation of denser or less dense structures is achieved, whereas temperature along with coordination patterns exhibited by both the metal node and organic linkers are accountable for the formation of kinetic products. Our group previously reported the different structural phases and polymorphs involved in the formation of Cu dimers bridged by phosphonic acid, where both the temperature and coordination geometry play an important role. When addressing crystallizations at room temperature through solvent evaporation, diffusion, or layering techniques, synthetic parameters such as diffusion control of solvents, concentration of reactants, and rate of evaporation direct the formation of different structural phases. The stability of these phases depends upon the coordinative restraints applied by both the linkers and metal coordination spheres. Hence, the factors that drive the formation of stable forms through the intermediate phases are needed to investigate in depth to evaluate the stability of the final phases when exposed to different external stimuli.

elements.content: Coordination polymers incorporating Na+ nodes are very rare due to their tendency to accept a large number of solvent molecules into their coordination sphere. Nonetheless, these materials have recently emerged as promising candidates for sodium ion batteries (SIB). Yaghi et al. reported two Na-based MOFs that are formed from stable Na-metal oxide two-dimensional (2-D) sheets connected by a tetratopic linker to form three-dimensional (3-D) architectures. Mobin et al. reported the observation of single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations in Na-based MOFs under a vacuum, in which the coordination connectivity of the triazole ring changes during the transformation. Tetrazole and triazole rings show different coordination modes in their architectures owing to the presence of more coordinating nitrogen atoms. These types of linkers generally lead to metastable phases which undergo structural transformations, resulting in the eventual formation of more thermodynamically stable coordination polymers. Metastable MOFs based on 5-amino tetrazole were stabilized by Pang et al. by encapsulation of graphene oxide.

elements.content: We now present the investigation of structural transformations involved in the formation Na-based coordination polymers with the bitetrazole linker 1,2-bis­(tetrazol-5-yl)­ethane (H2 bte). A search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) revealed that H2 bte is poorly explored, exemplified by the fact that only two coordination polymers were reported with Zn and Na. Herein we report six new Na-based coordination polymers incorporating H2 bte as the linker, three of which were obtained as intermediates in the formation of the three final products in the reaction mixture. Solvent layering of a solution containing H2 bte and NaOH led to the formation of [Na­(Hbte)­(CH3OH)2] n (1), which was isolated first as an intermediate phase. Further reaction resulted in the structural transformation of 1 into [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)3] n (2). Adding NH3 along with NaOH resulted in the production of an intermediate 2-D compound [Na2(bte)­(H2O)3] n (3), after which the final product [Na2(bte)2(H2O)3] n ­·2NH4·H2O (4) was obtained. Finally, by using the solvent CH3CN and NaOH, the formation of [Na2(Hbte)2­(H2O)] n (6) was achieved, which crystallized via the intermediate [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)] n (5). The intermediate compounds which formed initially are converted to final products in the reaction mixture. The structural parameters responsible for transformation toward the final compound and noncovalent interactions that stabilizes the final compound were studied in detail. The compounds were structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, and the stable phases were additionally characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

elements.content: All chemicals are commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The ligand H2 bte was synthesized according to the procedure reported by Sharpless et al.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals are commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The ligand H2 bte was synthesized according to the procedure reported by Sharpless et al.

elements.content: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was carried out on a Mettler Toledo DSC3+ instrument and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TA Q500 instrument, using dry nitrogen atmosphere, at a rate of 20 mL/min. About 0.5–1 mg samples were sealed in aluminum pans for DSC measurements with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, between 25 and 450 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer at 60 kV, 30 mA, and CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 1°/min and a step size of 0.02°.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was carried out on a Mettler Toledo DSC3+ instrument and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a TA Q500 instrument, using dry nitrogen atmosphere, at a rate of 20 mL/min. About 0.5-1 mg samples were sealed in aluminum pans for DSC measurements with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, between 25 and 450 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer at 60 kV, 30 mA, and CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 1°/min and a step size of 0.02°.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements performed on Bruker-Apex Duo diffractometer with IμS microfocus using MoKα radiation. Measurements were carried out at 110 (2) K on crystals coated with a thin layer of amorphous oil. The structures were solved by direct and Fourier methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares, using standard crystallographic software: SHELXT-2014, SHELXL-2014. The TOPOS software package was used to analyze the topological features of the available framework solids. Thermal ellipsoidal plot diagrams of the asymmetric units in compounds 1–6 are shown in the . Crystal data and structural refinement details of compounds 1–6 are presented in . Complete list of bond lengths and bond angles are shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Measurement

Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements performed on Bruker-Apex Duo diffractometer with IμS microfocus using MoKα radiation. Measurements were carried out at 110 (2) K on crystals coated with a thin layer of amorphous oil. The structures were solved by direct and Fourier methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares, using standard crystallographic software: SHELXT-2014, SHELXL-2014. The TOPOS software package was used to analyze the topological features of the available framework solids. Thermal ellipsoidal plot diagrams of the asymmetric units in compounds 1-6 are shown in the . Crystal data and structural refinement details of compounds 1-6 are presented in . Complete list of bond lengths and bond angles are shown in .

Synthesized following the Sharpless et al. procedure. To a suspension of fumaronitrile (3.12 g, 40.0 mmol) in water (80.0 mL), sodium azide (5.72 g, 88.0 mmol) and zinc bromide (18.0 g, 80.0 mmol) were added. The mixture was heated to reflux overnight and then cooled to room temperature and 60.0 mL of 3 M HCl was added. The yellow precipitate formed was filtered and dissolved in water (50.0 mL). Solid NaOH (4.0 g, 0.1 mol) was added to obtain pH 12; a orange clear solution formed and was stirred for 30 min, and during that time the remaining Zn­(OH)2 crystallized. The solution was filtered and conc. HCl (8.0 mL) added to the filtrate to obtain pH 4.5, which allowed the product to precipitate. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and air-dried to afford bright yellow powder (87%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ 7.54 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO) δ 153.25 (s), 119.48 (s). IR (ATR) 3094 (s), 3039 (s), 2866 (m), 2751 (w), 1677 (w), 1545 (s), 1426 (m), 1367 (m), 1244 (m), 1212­(m), 1067 (s), 1008 (s), 842 (s), 755 (s), 503 (s). MS (ES-) 185.1 m/z [M – 2H + Na].

Synthetic Procedures

Synthesis of H2 bte 

Synthesized following the Sharpless et al. procedure. To a suspension of fumaronitrile (3.12 g, 40.0 mmol) in water (80.0 mL), sodium azide (5.72 g, 88.0 mmol) and zinc bromide (18.0 g, 80.0 mmol) were added. The mixture was heated to reflux overnight and then cooled to room temperature and 60.0 mL of 3 M HCl was added. The yellow precipitate formed was filtered and dissolved in water (50.0 mL). Solid NaOH (4.0 g, 0.1 mol) was added to obtain pH 12; a orange clear solution formed and was stirred for 30 min, and during that time the remaining Zn(OH)2 crystallized. The solution was filtered and conc. HCl (8.0 mL) added to the filtrate to obtain pH 4.5, which allowed the product to precipitate. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and air-dried to afford bright yellow powder (87%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ 7.54 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO) δ 153.25 (s), 119.48 (s). IR (ATR) 3094 (s), 3039 (s), 2866 (m), 2751 (w), 1677 (w), 1545 (s), 1426 (m), 1367 (m), 1244 (m), 1212(m), 1067 (s), 1008 (s), 842 (s), 755 (s), 503 (s). MS (ES-) 185.1 m/z [M - 2H + Na].

elements.content: H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was layered over a solution of NaOH (1.0 mg, 0.025 mmol) in deionized water (1.5 mL), with a separating layer of 1.0 mL of toluene. After 2 days, colorless block crystals of compound 1 were observed on the walls of the glass vial (∼5–6% based on Na). After 6 days colorless needles of compound 2 were found in large quantities in the glass vial which were separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (54% based on sodium). Anal. Calcd for C6H11N8NaO2 (1): C, 28.80; H, 4.43; N, 44.79. Found: C, 29.10; H, 4.23; N, 44.69 Anal. Calcd for C4H9N8NaO3 (2): C, 20.00; H, 3.78; N, 46.66. Found: C, 19.72; H, 4.05; N, 46.22.

H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was layered over a solution of NaOH (1.0 mg, 0.025 mmol) in deionized water (1.5 mL), with a separating layer of 1.0 mL of toluene. After 2 days, colorless block crystals of compound 1 were observed on the walls of the glass vial (~5-6% based on Na). After 6 days colorless needles of compound 2 were found in large quantities in the glass vial which were separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (54% based on sodium). Anal. elements.content: Compounds 3 and 4 were obtained from the same reaction mixture as intermediate and stable phases. 1.0 mL of toluene was layered on the solution of NaOH (1 mg, 0.025 mmol) in aqueous ammonia (25%, 1.5 mL), to this mixture a solution of H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was carefully layered and covered with aluminum foil. After 2 days a few cubic colorless crystals of compound 3 were observed on the walls (∼ 4% based on Na). After 6 days, colorless needles of compound 4 were obtained from reaction mixture which was separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (87% based on Na). Anal. Compounds 3 and 4 were obtained from the same reaction mixture as intermediate and stable phases. 1.0 mL of toluene was layered on the solution of NaOH (1 mg, 0.025 mmol) in aqueous ammonia (25%, 1.5 mL), to this mixture a solution of H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was carefully layered and covered with aluminum foil. After 2 days a few cubic colorless crystals of compound 3 were observed on the walls (~ 4% based on Na). After 6 days, colorless needles of compound 4 were obtained from reaction mixture which was separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (87% based on Na). Anal. elements.content: H2 bte (5.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of acetonitrile (2.0 mL) and 250.0 μL of MeOH in a glass vial. Powdered NaOH (1.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was added to reaction mixture and swirled to achieve complete solubility. The mixture was sealed in a screw cap vial, heated at 90 °C in a bath reactor for 4 h, cooled slowly to room temperature, and kept open for evaporation. Immediately after 1 day, colorless prismatic crystals of compound 5 were obtained on the walls, and after 4 days colorless rod-like crystals of 6 were obtained on the bottom of the vial, which were collected by filtration, washed with cold water, and dried in air (77% based on sodium). Anal. Calcd for C4H5N8NaO (5): C, 23.54; H, 2.47; N, 54.89. Found: C, 23.24; H, 2.22; N, 54.78 Anal. Calcd for C8H8N16Na2O (6): C, 24.62; H, 2.07; N, 57.43. Found: C, 24.77; H, 1.88; N, 57.87.

H2 bte (5.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of acetonitrile (2.0 mL) and 250.0 μL of MeOH in a glass vial. Powdered NaOH (1.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was added to reaction mixture and swirled to achieve complete solubility. The mixture was sealed in a screw cap vial, heated at 90 °C in a bath reactor for 4 h, cooled slowly to room temperature, and kept open for evaporation. Immediately after 1 day, colorless prismatic crystals of compound 5 were obtained on the walls, and after 4 days colorless rod-like crystals of 6 were obtained on the bottom of the vial, which were collected by filtration, washed with cold water, and dried in air (77% based on sodium). elements.content: The H2 bte ligand was synthesized by dipolar cycloaddition from fumaronitrile (1,2-dicyanoethylene) and sodium azide, using an equimolar amount of zinc bromide as a Lewis acid. The skeleton of ligand geometry is rigid in nature and has eight coordination sites, which make the linker more reactive with metal centers. As a result, this ditetrazole scaffold readily yields amorphous precipitates or, at best, microcrystalline phases. The growth of the crystals can be controlled by slowing down the fast deprotonation of the acidic proton which has a pK a of approximately 5. When the linker H2 bte was allowed to react with NaOH directly in water at room temperature, the formation of amorphous precipitate was observed after a few hours. Here, NaOH is used to deprotonate H2 bte, which encourages coordination with the metal center. Hence, in order to obtain the crystalline phases of Na-bte coordination assemblies, the reaction between the H2 bte and NaOH should be done in a controlled pathway. In order to achieve this, we adopted layering technique where the reactants are allowed to react in a controlled rate.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The H2 bte ligand was synthesized by dipolar cycloaddition from fumaronitrile (1,2-dicyanoethylene) and sodium azide, using an equimolar amount of zinc bromide as a Lewis acid. The skeleton of ligand geometry is rigid in nature and has eight coordination sites, which make the linker more reactive with metal centers. As a result, this ditetrazole scaffold readily yields amorphous precipitates or, at best, microcrystalline phases. The growth of the crystals can be controlled by slowing down the fast deprotonation of the acidic proton which has a pK a of approximately 5. When the linker H2 bte was allowed to react with NaOH directly in water at room temperature, the formation of amorphous precipitate was observed after a few hours. Here, NaOH is used to deprotonate H2 bte, which encourages coordination with the metal center. Hence, in order to obtain the crystalline phases of Na-bte coordination assemblies, the reaction between the H2 bte and NaOH should be done in a controlled pathway. In order to achieve this, we adopted layering technique where the reactants are allowed to react in a controlled rate.

elements.content: H2 bte was dissolved in MeOH and layered over solution of NaOH in H2O with toluene as an intermediate layer to obtain compounds 1 and 2. A few colorless block crystals of compound 1 were harvested from the walls of the glass vial and interface of two solutions after 2 days. The reaction vial was allowed to stand for another 4 days to obtain a large number of colorless needles consisting of 2. This reaction scheme put forward a few questions about whether compounds 1 and 2 are two different phases of Na-bte coordination assemblies or compound 1 is an intermediate phase during the formation of compound 2. We collected a few crystals of compound 1 and placed them in the reaction mixture consisting of H2 bte in MeOH and NaOH in H2O solvent mixture; these crystals get dissolved slowly in the reaction mixture and form compound 2 after 3–4 days. Also, cubic crystals of compound 1 were found to transform into needle-like crystals of 2 after 4 days when allowed to stand in the reaction vial. These two observations suggest the possibility that compound 1 consists of an intermediate phase in the formation of 2. In both compounds, the linker was partially deprotonated and exists in Hbte – form and coordinated to metal centers in the μ1-coordination mode.

A few colorless block crystals of compound 1 were harvested from the walls of the glass vial and interface of two solutions after 2 days. The reaction vial was allowed to stand for another 4 days to obtain a large number of colorless needles consisting of 2. This reaction scheme put forward a few questions about whether compounds 1 and 2 are two different phases of Na-bte coordination assemblies or compound 1 is an intermediate phase during the formation of compound 2. We collected a few crystals of compound 1 and placed them in the reaction mixture consisting of H2 bte in MeOH and NaOH in H2O solvent mixture; these crystals get dissolved slowly in the reaction mixture and form compound 2 after 3-4 days. Also, cubic crystals of compound 1 were found to transform into needle-like crystals of 2 after 4 days when allowed to stand in the reaction vial. These two observations suggest the possibility that compound 1 consists of an intermediate phase in the formation of 2. In both compounds, the linker was partially deprotonated and exists in Hbte - form and coordinated to metal centers in the μ1-coordination mode.

elements.content: The deprotonation of ligand precursor is an important key step to achieve complexation of metal precursor with the ligand to form coordination architectures. In the second attempt, a MeOH solution of H2 bte was layered on an ammonical (NH4OH) solution of NaOH with toluene as an intermediate layer. Gaseous NH3 forms upon a mixture of NaOH(aq) and NH4OH(aq), which slowly diffuses into the methanolic solution of H2 bte, leading to complete deprotonation of the tetrazole rings. These deprotonated bte 2– linkers diffuse slowly into the alkali solution to form Na-bte coordination assemblies. The purpose of adding NH3 along with NaOH is to deprotonate the H2 bte linker more effectively in a controlled rate. By employing this strategy, we obtained two different phases, 3 and 4, in the reaction vial. Two days after setting up the layering experiment, the formation of colorless cubic crystals of 3 was observed, which then converted to needle-shaped crystals of 4 after 6 days. This was consistent with 3 being an intermediate in the formation of 4. In compounds 3 and 4 the linker was fully deprotonated to its dianionic form bte 2– and coordinates to sodium centers in μ1,2- and μ2,3-coordination modes.

elements.content: In another attempt to obtain crystalline Na-bte coordination assemblies, the reaction mixture consisting of H2 bte and NaOH in a solvent mixture of CH3CN and MeOH was heated at 90 °C and allowed to cool to room temperature. The reaction mixture was then allowed to evaporate slowly to obtain crystals of 5 after 1 day and 6 in 4 days. Reacting H2 bte and NaOH at higher temperature resulted in partial deprotonation of H2 bte to Hbte –.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Protocol of Compounds Presented in the Study

elements.content: The linker H2 bte was crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅ from hot water as colorless block crystals. A strong hydrogen bond exists between two adjacent molecules through N–H···N interactions (N1–H1···N2, d N···N = 2.986(17) Å) to form 1-D supramolecular chains (). These chains are held together by weak N–H···π supramolecular interactions between the tetrazole ring and NH groups from parallel planes.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

H2 bte 

The linker H2 bte was crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅ from hot water as colorless block crystals. A strong hydrogen bond exists between two adjacent molecules through N-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions (N1-H1⋅⋅⋅N2, d N⋅⋅⋅N = 2.986(17) Å) to form 1-D supramolecular chains (). These chains are held together by weak N-H⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions between the tetrazole ring and NH groups from parallel planes.

elements.content: 1-D supramolecular chains formed due to N–H···N interactions between the H2 bte linkers (Right) and packing arrangement of H2 bte linkers (Left).
elements.clean_text: 1  1-D supramolecular chains formed due to N-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions between the H2 bte linkers (Right) and packing arrangement of H2 bte linkers (Left).

elements.content: The linker exhibits planarity in the crystal structure with a torsion angle of 180° (C2–C3–C3–C2) between two tetrazole rings due to conjugate ethylene bridge. From the packing diagram, the arrangement of H2 bte linkers indicates the most stable conformation, and the linker is inclined to adopt this type of arrangement in its coordination architectures.
elements.clean_text: The linker exhibits planarity in the crystal structure with a torsion angle of 180° (C2-C3-C3-C2) between two tetrazole rings due to conjugate ethylene bridge. From the packing diagram, the arrangement of H2 bte linkers indicates the most stable conformation, and the linker is inclined to adopt this type of arrangement in its coordination architectures.

elements.content: Compound 1 and compound 2 are a set of intermediate and final phases respectively obtained by layering a solution of H2 bte on NaOH(aq). Compound 1 is a metastable phase formed during the crystallization of compound 2 and obtained in very low yields. Also compound 1 converts to 2 during the process of crystallization. [Na­(Hbte)­(CH3OH)2] n (1) crystallizes in a face-centered monoclinic space group symmetry of C2/c. The building block in compound 1 consists of an infinite 1-D {Na­(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chain in which Na exists in a NaN2O4 octahedral coordination sphere. The solvent MeOH molecule acts as μ2-bridging linker connecting Na nodes to form infinite 1-D chains oriented parallel to the crystallographic b-axis (a).
elements.clean_text:
Compounds 1 and 2 

Compound 1 and compound 2 are a set of intermediate and final phases respectively obtained by layering a solution of H2 bte on NaOH(aq). Compound 1 is a metastable phase formed during the crystallization of compound 2 and obtained in very low yields. Also compound 1 converts to 2 during the process of crystallization. [Na(Hbte)(CH3OH)2] n  (1) crystallizes in a face-centered monoclinic space group symmetry of C2/c. The building block in compound 1 consists of an infinite 1-D {Na(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chain in which Na exists in a NaN2O4 octahedral coordination sphere. The solvent MeOH molecule acts as μ2-bridging linker connecting Na nodes to form infinite 1-D chains oriented parallel to the crystallographic b-axis (a).

elements.content: (a) 1-D {Na­(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chains formed in compound 1. (b) 2-D sheets observed due to connectivity between 1-D chains through Hbte linkers. (c) Tubular channel like arrangement of 2-D sheets.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 1-D {Na(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chains formed in compound 1. (b) 2-D sheets observed due to connectivity between 1-D chains through Hbte linkers. (c) Tubular channel like arrangement of 2-D sheets.

elements.content: Those chains are connected to each other by the Hbte linker in dipodal fashion to form 2-D sheets as shown in b. The linker adopts coordination mode II on one or both tetrazole rings, depending on if the linker is protonated (see ). The dipodal connectivity of the Hbte linker to the Na metal center of the 1-D chain results a tubular channel-like arrangement in the 2-D sheets as shown in the c. Topological analysis of the structure performed by TOPAS reveals the structure is 2D network showing a topology of 4-connected uninodal net with a point symbol of {66} (see ).

elements.content: Compound 2 is a 1-D coordination polymer crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅ and characterized by the molecular formula [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)3] n . Compound 2 is built from {Na­(μ2-H2O)}2 dimers in which Na atom exists in {NaNO5} octahedral geometry constituted from four bridging and one terminal aqua ligands, and one Hbte – ligand (a). The Hbte – molecules do not display bridging or dipodal connectivity to increase the dimensionality of the structure; instead, they act as terminal μ1-ligands coordinating to Na+ ions on each side of the 1-D polymer. The terminal aqua ligands of the 1-D chains are connected by O–H···O (O2–H2B···O3, d C···O = 2.799(1) Å, with symmetry operator x, 1 + y, z) hydrogen bonding interactions to form 2-D supramolecular sheets of composition {Na­(μ2-H2O)} n (b) with Hbte – linkers hanging above and below the sheets. These hanging Hbte – linkers connect to other {Na­(μ2-H2O)} n supramolecular sheets through O–H···N (O3–H3B···N3, d o···N = 2.703(1) Å, with symmetry operator −1 + x, y, 1 + z) interactions to form a 3-D supramolecular hydrogen-bonded framework.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2 is a 1-D coordination polymer crystallized in triclinic space group P1̅ and characterized by the molecular formula [Na(Hbte)(H2O)3] n . Compound 2 is built from {Na(μ2-H2O)}2 dimers in which Na atom exists in {NaNO5} octahedral geometry constituted from four bridging and one terminal aqua ligands, and one Hbte - ligand (a). The Hbte - molecules do not display bridging or dipodal connectivity to increase the dimensionality of the structure; instead, they act as terminal μ1-ligands coordinating to Na+ ions on each side of the 1-D polymer. The terminal aqua ligands of the 1-D chains are connected by O-H⋅⋅⋅O (O2-H2B⋅⋅⋅O3, d C⋅⋅⋅O = 2.799(1) Å, with symmetry operator x, 1 + y, z) hydrogen bonding interactions to form 2-D supramolecular sheets of composition {Na(μ2-H2O)} n  (b) with Hbte - linkers hanging above and below the sheets. These hanging Hbte - linkers connect to other {Na(μ2-H2O)} n  supramolecular sheets through O-H⋅⋅⋅N (O3-H3B⋅⋅⋅N3, d o⋅⋅⋅N = 2.703(1) Å, with symmetry operator -1 + x, y, 1 + z) interactions to form a 3-D supramolecular hydrogen-bonded framework.

elements.content: Compound 3 and compound 4 are metastable, and final products of crystallization obtained by layering a methanolic solution of H2 bte on NaOH in aqueous NH3. Colorless block crystals of compound 3 were obtained as the initial kinetic product in the crystallization of 4. The [Na2(bte)­(H2O)3] n formula characterizes the 3-D framework in 3 and crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The 3-D framework was built on 1-D {Na­(H2O)} n chains running through the crystallographic c-axis (a). The repeating unit in the chain is a cyclic {Na­(H2O)}4 tetramer. The Na atoms in the tetramer are coordinated in square pyramidal coordination geometry to two N atoms from two different bte 2– ligands and oxygen atoms from three bridging water molecules (b). These infinite 1-D chains are interlinked with each other through μ1,2 bridging bte 2– linkers in a dipodal fashion to form a 3-D architecture as shown in b. Correspondingly, the structure can be described as a 6,6-connected binodal net with network topology {3.24.45.46.372}­{3.24.55.563}2 as shown in . The Na–N bond lengths observed in the framework are 2.445 and 2.485 Å, and a long-range Na–N interaction of bond length 2.684 (2) Å further reinforces the 3-D architecture.

Compounds 3 and 4

Colorless block crystals of compound 3 were obtained as the initial kinetic product in the crystallization of 4. The [Na2(bte)(H2O)3] n  formula characterizes the 3-D framework in 3 and crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The 3-D framework was built on 1-D {Na(H2O)} n  chains running through the crystallographic c-axis (a). The repeating unit in the chain is a cyclic {Na(H2O)}4 tetramer. The Na atoms in the tetramer are coordinated in square pyramidal coordination geometry to two N atoms from two different bte 2- ligands and oxygen atoms from three bridging water molecules (b). These infinite 1-D chains are interlinked with each other through μ1,2 bridging bte 2- linkers in a dipodal fashion to form a 3-D architecture as shown in b. Correspondingly, the structure can be described as a 6,6-connected binodal net with network topology {3.24.45.46.372}{3.24.55.563}2 as shown in . The Na-N bond lengths observed in the framework are 2.445 and 2.485 Å, and a long-range Na-N interaction of bond length 2.684 (2) Å further reinforces the 3-D architecture.

elements.content: Compound 4 is a 1-D coordination polymer with formula [(Na2(bte)2(H2O)3)­·2NH4·H2O] n which crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. The molecular structure consists of two crystallographically independent Na atoms in tetrahedral geometry. Two bridging and one terminal aqua ligands, as well as one terminal bte 2–, constitute the coordination sphere {NaO3N} of Na(1), whereas the Na(2) coordination sphere {NaN2O2} is furnished by two bridging aqua ligands and two different bridging bte 2– molecules. This type of coordination leads to the formation of cyclic {Na­(H2O)}4 tetramers that are connected to bridging bte 2– ligands that bind in the μ2,3 mode, leading to the formation of 1-D extended chains as shown in a. The nitrogen atoms present in the other tetrazole ring of the μ2,3 bridging bte 2– ligands are involved in long-range interactions with Na­(I) and Na(2) atoms of another chain to form 2-D extended supramolecular layers (bond distances Na(1)–N(8): 2.580 (1) Å, Na(2)–N8: 2.597(1) Å, Na(1)–N10: 2.662 (1) Å, Na(2)–N10: 2.699(1) Å). These interactions stabilize the Na atoms in an octahedral coordination sphere and prevent the excess hydration of the Na atoms (b). On the other hand, the other tetrazole ring of terminal bte 2– ligands connected to the Na­(I) remains inoperative.

elements.content: Ammonium cations are intercalated in the void spaces of the supramolecular layers and serve to balance the charge on the bte 2– ligands. The 1-D chain in the compound is stabilized by a range of various supramolecular interactions viz. O–H···O interactions between lattice and coordinated water molecules, N+–H···N interactions between lattice NH4 + ions and N atoms of tetrazole ring, and O–H···N interactions between coordinated water molecules and N atoms of the tetrazole ring.

elements.content: Compounds 5 and 6 represent metastable and stable forms of another set of Na-bte coordination polymers. Compound 5 is a metastable 2-D polymer crystallizing in monoclinic space group Cc and characterized by the formula [Na­(Hbte)­(H2O)] n . An infinite 1-D Na­(μ2-H2O) chain is formed along the crystallographic c-axis in which the Na atom resides in a tetrahedral coordination sphere. The distortion parameter τ4, calculated by the four-coordinate geometry index (τ4 = {360° – (α + β)}/141) around the Na tetrahedral coordination sphere is nearly 0.63. These 1-D chains are linked by Hbte – linkers in a μ1 dipodal coordination mode along the c-axis to form a 2-D coordination polymer (Na(1)–N(6): 2.424 (1) Å). Hence, the coordination sphere of Na atom is {NaN2O2} which is furnished by two oxygen atoms from two μ2-H2O ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two Hbte – linkers. The overall connectivity results in the formation of zigzag 2D coordination networks. The structure can be simplified as 3,6-connected binodal network with point symbol of {43}2{4.66.683} and the topological representation was shown in . The bridging μ2-H2O linkers and protonated tetrazole ring of Hbte – are involved in strong hydrogen bonding, resulting in the extension of the 2-dimensional layers into a 3-D supramolecular framework.
elements.clean_text:
Compounds 5 and 6 

Compounds 5 and 6 represent metastable and stable forms of another set of Na-bte coordination polymers. Compound 5 is a metastable 2-D polymer crystallizing in monoclinic space group Cc and characterized by the formula [Na(Hbte)(H2O)] n . An infinite 1-D Na(μ2-H2O) chain is formed along the crystallographic c-axis in which the Na atom resides in a tetrahedral coordination sphere. The distortion parameter τ4, calculated by the four-coordinate geometry index (τ4 = {360° - (α + β)}/141) around the Na tetrahedral coordination sphere is nearly 0.63. These 1-D chains are linked by Hbte - linkers in a μ1 dipodal coordination mode along the c-axis to form a 2-D coordination polymer (Na(1)-N(6): 2.424 (1) Å). Hence, the coordination sphere of Na atom is {NaN2O2} which is furnished by two oxygen atoms from two μ2-H2O ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two Hbte - linkers. The overall connectivity results in the formation of zigzag 2D coordination networks. The structure can be simplified as 3,6-connected binodal network with point symbol of {43}2{4.66.683} and the topological representation was shown in . The bridging μ2-H2O linkers and protonated tetrazole ring of Hbte - are involved in strong hydrogen bonding, resulting in the extension of the 2-dimensional layers into a 3-D supramolecular framework.

elements.content: Compound 6 is a stable 2-D coordination polymer that crystallizes in monoclinic space group symmetry C2/c. Due to elevated temperatures employed in the synthesis, the number of aqua ligands in the Na coordination sphere is lower compared to the number of tetrazole linkers. The Na atom resides in tetrahedral geometry {NaN3O} with three N atoms from three different Hbte – linkers and one bridging water molecule. The distortion parameter τ4 for the tetrahedral geometry of the Na coordination sphere is observed as 0.77. The deprotonated ring of Hbte – coordinates to the three Na atoms in the μ1,2,3 coordination mode (Mode-VIII) to form an extended 1-D chain running through the crystallographic b-axis (Na(1)–N(8): 2.616 (1) Å, Na(1)–N7: 2.516(1) Å, Na(1)–N3: 2.536 (1) Å). These 1-D chains are linked with one another along the a-axis by the bridging water molecules resulting in 2-D sheets. The structure was simplified to a 4,8-connected binodal network with the Schlafli symbol of {4.126.1284}­{46}2, and the topological representation of the network is shown in . The tetrazole ring which is protonated remains coordinatively inactive and exhibits long-range interactions (Na(1)–N(4): 2.716 (1) Å) that stabilize the tetrahedral Na coordination sphere and extend these 2-D sheets into 3-D supramolecular frameworks.

Structural Transformation from Intermediate to Stable Phases

The formation of intermediate compounds and their transformation to stable compounds need to be investigated in detail to explore the formation pathways as well as the stability of the final phases. The structural transformation involved during the phase changes was discussed in detail.  represents the change in the composition from intermediate to final phases.

elements.content:
Blue color indicates intermediate phase, and red color indicates stable phase.

Compound 1 and compound 2 represent coordination polymers based on the μ1-coordination mode of the tetrazole linker employed. The colorless block crystals of compound 1 convert into colorless needles of 2 within a week when kept in the same reaction mixture. In both compounds, the polymers are constructed by {Na­(μ2-solvent)}2 (solvent = MeOH in 1 and H2O in 2) building blocks. During the process of conversion to stable form 2, the Na metal center loses one bulky Hbte molecule from its coordination sphere which is then occupied by the less bulky solvent water molecule. The transformation toward the stable form is also accompanied by the replacement of bridging bulkier MeOH molecules in the Na coordination sphere by less bulky H2O molecules (a). Hence the octahedral coordination sphere {NaN2(MeOH)4} in compound 1 transforms to {NaN­(H2O)5} in stable compound 2. Because of this rearrangement, one of the tetrazole rings of Hbte remains coordinatively free in form 2. Consequently, the stable phase is restricted to only one dimension, which allowed further stabilization by strong directional supramolecular interactions. The protonation of the linker remained the same in both the compounds whereas the coordination pattern changed during the transformation. The overall transformation was driven by the reduction in bulkiness in the coordination sphere of the Na metal center (b). The steric hindrance created by the linkers in the coordination sphere changes the coordination architectures of the final structures previously demonstrated by Das et al.

Compound 1 and compound 2 represent coordination polymers based on the μ1-coordination mode of the tetrazole linker employed. The colorless block crystals of compound 1 convert into colorless needles of 2 within a week when kept in the same reaction mixture. In both compounds, the polymers are constructed by {Na(μ2-solvent)}2 (solvent = MeOH in 1 and H2O in 2) building blocks. During the process of conversion to stable form 2, the Na metal center loses one bulky Hbte molecule from its coordination sphere which is then occupied by the less bulky solvent water molecule. The transformation toward the stable form is also accompanied by the replacement of bridging bulkier MeOH molecules in the Na coordination sphere by less bulky H2O molecules (a). Hence the octahedral coordination sphere {NaN2(MeOH)4} in compound 1 transforms to {NaN(H2O)5} in stable compound 2. Because of this rearrangement, one of the tetrazole rings of Hbte remains coordinatively free in form 2. Consequently, the stable phase is restricted to only one dimension, which allowed further stabilization by strong directional supramolecular interactions. The protonation of the linker remained the same in both the compounds whereas the coordination pattern changed during the transformation. The overall transformation was driven by the reduction in bulkiness in the coordination sphere of the Na metal center (b). The steric hindrance created by the linkers in the coordination sphere changes the coordination architectures of the final structures previously demonstrated by Das et al.

elements.content: Compound 3 represents a metastable product which is characterized by infinite {Na­(H2O)}4 tetramer chains bridged by the bte 2– linkers to form a 3-D framework, whereas 4 represents the thermodynamically stable product characterized by discrete {Na­(H2O)}4 tetramers bridged by the bte 2– linkers to form 1-D chains. Compound 3 gradually changes into 4 upon standing in the mother liquor. This gradual transformation indicates the thermodynamic stability of 4, and during this process various changes in the crystal structure were observed. Slight variations in the density and steric hindrance around the Na coordination sphere direct the structural change toward the stable phase. During the conversion process, the coordination sphere of the Na atom, which starts out as square pyramidal {NaN2O3} in metastable phase 3, changes to tetrahedral {NaNO3}/{NaN2O2} in 4 as shown in ; hence that is why the dimensionality is restricted to only direction in stable phase. The rearrangement around the Na coordination sphere drives the changes in coordination patterns of the bte 2– linkers, and as a result the inclusion of ammonium cations into the structure was observed in the stable phase. The geometry and protonation of the linker bte 2– is not affected much during the process of conversion, but the μ2,3-coordination mode of the bte 2– linker changes to μ1,2-coordination mode.

elements.content: Compounds 5 and 6 are coordination polymers obtained at a temperature of nearly 100 °C in which compound 6 represents the stable form and 5 is the metastable form. The reaction was performed at higher temperatures to minimize the coordination of solvent molecules to Na and thus increase the level of bte linkers in the Na coordination sphere. During the formation of stable form 6 through the metastable form 5, a series of structural changes were observed. Compound 5 is characterized by infinite 1-D chains with Na­(μ2-H2O) building blocks; however, in 5 the same building block exists but bte linkers intervene to form another structural architecture (a). The coordination mode of the tetrazole linker changes from the μ1 to μ1,2,3 and dipodal to uninodal during the process of 5 converting to 6. The coordination sphere around the Na atom remains tetrahedral during the process of conversion but changes from {NaN2O4} in 5 to {NaN3O} in 6. In addition to this, the distortion in the tetrahedral geometry around the Na metal center also decreases during the process, and the stable phase coordination sphere achieves a more ideal tetrahedral geometry (b). The structural changes during the formation of 6 via 5 are driven by factors like a decrease in distortion of tetrahedral geometry to accommodate a greater number of N atoms in the coordination sphere. The structural change from metastable to stable form does not affect the dimensionality, unlike the above two cases.

elements.content: On the basis of the examples, it is observed that during the process of attaining stable form the dimensionality of the coordination polymer reduces. In other words, during this process, one of the tetrazole rings of the bte linker which is coordinatively active in the metastable form becomes inactive in the stable form; hence, the dimensionality of the polymer decreases.

elements.content: To ensure the phase purity of the stable compounds (2, 4, and 6) presented in this study, X-ray diffraction patterns of powder samples have been recorded. The diffraction patterns for the simulated data (calculated from single crystal data) are well matched with the observed data, which proves the bulk homogeneity of the crystalline solids (see ). The experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction peaks, and some peaks are slightly broadened and shifted in comparison to those simulated patterns probably due to the effects of the unidentified or intermediate phases.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Analysis

To ensure the phase purity of the stable compounds (2, 4, and 6) presented in this study, X-ray diffraction patterns of powder samples have been recorded. The diffraction patterns for the simulated data (calculated from single crystal data) are well matched with the observed data, which proves the bulk homogeneity of the crystalline solids (see ). The experimental patterns have a few unindexed diffraction peaks, and some peaks are slightly broadened and shifted in comparison to those simulated patterns probably due to the effects of the unidentified or intermediate phases.

elements.content: The thermal stability of the compounds has been characterized by TGA experiments which were performed under N2 for the crystalline samples of H2 bte linker and compounds 2, 4, and 6, in the temperature range 40–500 °C (see ). Compounds 1, 3, and 5 are highly unstable and obtained in very low yields; hence, the thermal analyses of these compounds are not performed. Compound 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 24% from room temperature to 110 °C corresponding to two coordinated and one interstitial water molecules. The dehydrated framework remains stable up to 385 °C and shows a minimal weight loss of 3.5% in this region (calculated weight loss of water molecules is 23%). The excess weight loss observed in this region may be due to partial decomposition of the bte linkers. The dehydrated framework undergoes decomposition and shows continuous weight loss at higher temperatures. Compound 4 shows an initial weight loss of 19.5% in the temperature regime of 90–135 °C, and the compound remains stable up to 370 °C with a small weight loss of 3.5%. The total weight loss in the region 30–370 °C is 23%, which is attributed to lattice and coordinated water molecules as well as interstitial ammonium cations (theoretical weight loss is 22.2%). The dehydrated compound starts decomposing on further heating from 370 °C and continues a gradual weight loss at higher temperatures. In compound 6 an initial weight loss of 5.5% was observed in the region 90–130 °C and another step of weight loss 2.5% from 130 to 180 °C. The total weight loss in the temperature region of 90–180 °C is 8.0%, which is due to lattice water molecules (the theoretical weight loss is 4.5%). The dehydrated framework remains stable up to 350 °C and undergoes decomposition at higher temperatures. All the compounds lose solvent molecules at lower temperatures, and the dehydrated compounds remains stable nearly up to 370 °C. In comparison pure H2bte decomposes at 280 °C, whereas all the coordination compounds decompose in the region 350–390 °C.

elements.content: Several endothermic peaks were observed in the DSC curves of all the compounds at lower temperatures ranging from 40 to 150 °C. These peaks are observed due to expulsion of coordinated and lattice water molecules from the network which are consistent with the TGA data. The dehydrated frameworks show exothermic peaks at 388 °C for 2, 358 °C for 4, and 362 °C for 6 which was assigned to decomposition of the frameworks.

elements.content: The article highlights the structural changes involved in the formation of stable form of coordination polymers through the intermediate forms. Six new coordination polymers based on Na-1,2-bis­(tetrazol-5-yl)­ethane (H2 bte) were crystallized through diffusion techniques. The exchange of solvent molecules depends on the rate of substitution, which in turn depends on the steric hindrance in the coordination sphere. The presence of bulky solvent MeOH molecules in compound 1 increases the steric hindrance in the Na­(I) octahedral coordination sphere; consequently, the solvent molecules were exchanged with less bulkier H2O molecules to obtain the more stable form compound 2. Structural changes involved in transformation of intermediate 3-D compound 3 to the stable 1-D compound 4 are driven to reduce crowdedness in Na­(I) coordination sphere from square pyramidal to tetrahedral as well as to attain stability provided by additional supramolecular interactions. In order reduce the distortion in Na­(I) tetrahedral coordination sphere in intermediate compound 5 (τ4 = 0.63) it accommodates additional bte linkers and transforms to stable compound 6 (τ4 = 0.77). The coordination assemblies observed in the metastable forms are relatively unstable and tend to rearrange to form the stable coordination assemblies. The compounds reported in this article represent the new horizons to understand the structural transformations involved in the self-assembly process during the crystallization of coordination polymers. During this process, factors like steric hindrance or crowdedness in metal coordination sphere, secondary interactions, and ligand confirmations drive the structural changes that lead to the formation of the more stable phases from the metastable intermediates. More systematic studies are underway to rationalize the factors discussed to understand the formation pathways of coordination polymers during the process of crystallization.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The article highlights the structural changes involved in the formation of stable form of coordination polymers through the intermediate forms. Six new coordination polymers based on Na-1,2-bis(tetrazol-5-yl)ethane (H2 bte) were crystallized through diffusion techniques. The exchange of solvent molecules depends on the rate of substitution, which in turn depends on the steric hindrance in the coordination sphere. The presence of bulky solvent MeOH molecules in compound 1 increases the steric hindrance in the Na(I) octahedral coordination sphere; consequently, the solvent molecules were exchanged with less bulkier H2O molecules to obtain the more stable form compound 2. Structural changes involved in transformation of intermediate 3-D compound 3 to the stable 1-D compound 4 are driven to reduce crowdedness in Na(I) coordination sphere from square pyramidal to tetrahedral as well as to attain stability provided by additional supramolecular interactions. In order reduce the distortion in Na(I) tetrahedral coordination sphere in intermediate compound 5 (τ4 = 0.63) it accommodates additional bte linkers and transforms to stable compound 6 (τ4 = 0.77). The coordination assemblies observed in the metastable forms are relatively unstable and tend to rearrange to form the stable coordination assemblies. The compounds reported in this article represent the new horizons to understand the structural transformations involved in the self-assembly process during the crystallization of coordination polymers. During this process, factors like steric hindrance or crowdedness in metal coordination sphere, secondary interactions, and ligand confirmations drive the structural changes that lead to the formation of the more stable phases from the metastable intermediates. More systematic studies are underway to rationalize the factors discussed to understand the formation pathways of coordination polymers during the process of crystallization.

Synthesized following the Sharpless et al. procedure. To a suspension of fumaronitrile (3.12 g, 40.0 mmol) in water (80.0 mL), sodium azide (5.72 g, 88.0 mmol) and zinc bromide (18.0 g, 80.0 mmol) were added. The mixture was heated to reflux overnight and then cooled to room temperature and 60.0 mL of 3 M HCl was added. The yellow precipitate formed was filtered and dissolved in water (50.0 mL). Solid NaOH (4.0 g, 0.1 mol) was added to obtain pH 12; a orange clear solution formed and was stirred for 30 min, and during that time the remaining Zn­(OH)2 crystallized. The solution was filtered and conc. HCl (8.0 mL) added to the filtrate to obtain pH 4.5, which allowed the product to precipitate. The precipitate was filtered, washed with water, and air-dried to afford bright yellow powder (87%). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO) δ 7.54 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO) δ 153.25 (s), 119.48 (s). IR (ATR) 3094 (s), 3039 (s), 2866 (m), 2751 (w), 1677 (w), 1545 (s), 1426 (m), 1367 (m), 1244 (m), 1212­(m), 1067 (s), 1008 (s), 842 (s), 755 (s), 503 (s). MS (ES-) 185.1 m/z [M – 2H + Na].

Synthesis of [Na­(H<bold>bte</bold>)­(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>) and [Na­(H<bold>bte</bold>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was layered over a solution of NaOH (1.0 mg, 0.025 mmol) in deionized water (1.5 mL), with a separating layer of 1.0 mL of toluene. After 2 days, colorless block crystals of compound 1 were observed on the walls of the glass vial (∼5–6% based on Na). After 6 days colorless needles of compound 2 were found in large quantities in the glass vial which were separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (54% based on sodium). Anal. Calcd for C6H11N8NaO2 (1): C, 28.80; H, 4.43; N, 44.79. Found: C, 29.10; H, 4.23; N, 44.69 Anal. Calcd for C4H9N8NaO3 (2): C, 20.00; H, 3.78; N, 46.66. Found: C, 19.72; H, 4.05; N, 46.22.

Synthesis of [Na<sub>2</sub>(<bold>bte</bold>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>) and [Na<sub>2</sub>(<bold>bte</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>·2NH<sub>4</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Compounds 3 and 4 were obtained from the same reaction mixture as intermediate and stable phases. 1.0 mL of toluene was layered on the solution of NaOH (1 mg, 0.025 mmol) in aqueous ammonia (25%, 1.5 mL), to this mixture a solution of H2 bte (8.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) dissolved in methanol (1.5 mL) was carefully layered and covered with aluminum foil. After 2 days a few cubic colorless crystals of compound 3 were observed on the walls (∼ 4% based on Na). After 6 days, colorless needles of compound 4 were obtained from reaction mixture which was separated, collected by filtration, and dried in air (87% based on Na). Anal. Calcd for C4H8N8Na2O3 (3): C, 18.33; H, 3.08; N, 42.75. Found: C, 18.10; H, 2.82; N, 43.00 Anal. Calcd for C8H20N18Na2O4 (4): C, 20.09; H, 4.21; N, 52.71. Found: C, 20.78; H, 4.05; N, 52.91.

Synthesis of [Na­(H<bold>bte</bold>)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>) and [Na<sub>2</sub>(H<bold>bte</bold>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

H2 bte (5.0 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in a mixture of acetonitrile (2.0 mL) and 250.0 μL of MeOH in a glass vial. Powdered NaOH (1.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was added to reaction mixture and swirled to achieve complete solubility. The mixture was sealed in a screw cap vial, heated at 90 °C in a bath reactor for 4 h, cooled slowly to room temperature, and kept open for evaporation. Immediately after 1 day, colorless prismatic crystals of compound 5 were obtained on the walls, and after 4 days colorless rod-like crystals of 6 were obtained on the bottom of the vial, which were collected by filtration, washed with cold water, and dried in air (77% based on sodium). Anal. Calcd for C4H5N8NaO (5): C, 23.54; H, 2.47; N, 54.89. Found: C, 23.24; H, 2.22; N, 54.78 Anal. Calcd for C8H8N16Na2O (6): C, 24.62; H, 2.07; N, 57.43. Found: C, 24.77; H, 1.88; N, 57.87.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of the compounds has been characterized by TGA experiments which were performed under N2 for the crystalline samples of H2 bte linker and compounds 2, 4, and 6, in the temperature range 40–500 °C (see ). Compounds 1, 3, and 5 are highly unstable and obtained in very low yields; hence, the thermal analyses of these compounds are not performed. Compound 2 shows a continuous weight loss of 24% from room temperature to 110 °C corresponding to two coordinated and one interstitial water molecules. The dehydrated framework remains stable up to 385 °C and shows a minimal weight loss of 3.5% in this region (calculated weight loss of water molecules is 23%). The excess weight loss observed in this region may be due to partial decomposition of the bte linkers. The dehydrated framework undergoes decomposition and shows continuous weight loss at higher temperatures. Compound 4 shows an initial weight loss of 19.5% in the temperature regime of 90–135 °C, and the compound remains stable up to 370 °C with a small weight loss of 3.5%. The total weight loss in the region 30–370 °C is 23%, which is attributed to lattice and coordinated water molecules as well as interstitial ammonium cations (theoretical weight loss is 22.2%). The dehydrated compound starts decomposing on further heating from 370 °C and continues a gradual weight loss at higher temperatures. In compound 6 an initial weight loss of 5.5% was observed in the region 90–130 °C and another step of weight loss 2.5% from 130 to 180 °C. The total weight loss in the temperature region of 90–180 °C is 8.0%, which is due to lattice water molecules (the theoretical weight loss is 4.5%). The dehydrated framework remains stable up to 350 °C and undergoes decomposition at higher temperatures. All the compounds lose solvent molecules at lower temperatures, and the dehydrated compounds remains stable nearly up to 370 °C. In comparison pure H2bte decomposes at 280 °C, whereas all the coordination compounds decompose in the region 350–390 °C.

Several endothermic peaks were observed in the DSC curves of all the compounds at lower temperatures ranging from 40 to 150 °C. These peaks are observed due to expulsion of coordinated and lattice water molecules from the network which are consistent with the TGA data. The dehydrated frameworks show exothermic peaks at 388 °C for 2, 358 °C for 4, and 362 °C for 6 which was assigned to decomposition of the frameworks.

cln_elements.content: 1-D supramolecular chains formed due to N–H···N interactions between the H2 bte linkers (Right) and packing arrangement of H2 bte linkers (Left).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  1-D supramolecular chains formed due to N-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions between the H2 bte linkers (Right) and packing arrangement of H2 bte linkers (Left).

cln_elements.content: (a) 1-D {Na­(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chains formed in compound 1. (b) 2-D sheets observed due to connectivity between 1-D chains through Hbte linkers. (c) Tubular channel like arrangement of 2-D sheets.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 1-D {Na(μ2-CH3OH)}2 chains formed in compound 1. (b) 2-D sheets observed due to connectivity between 1-D chains through Hbte linkers. (c) Tubular channel like arrangement of 2-D sheets.

cln_elements.content: (a) 1-D chain of compound 2 with {Na­(μ2-H2O)}2 building unit. (b) 2-D supramolecular sheet formed due to O–H···O interactions (bte linkers are omitted for clarity).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (a) 1-D chain of compound 2 with {Na(μ2-H2O)}2 building unit. (b) 2-D supramolecular sheet formed due to O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions (bte linkers are omitted for clarity).

cln_elements.content: (a) Representation of 1D tetrameric {Na­(H2O)}4 building block chain. (b) Fraction of 3-D framework projected parallel to the bc plane showing Na coordination sphere.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Representation of 1D tetrameric {Na(H2O)}4 building block chain. (b) Fraction of 3-D framework projected parallel to the bc plane showing Na coordination sphere.

cln_elements.content: (a) Cyclic tetramers bridged by a pair of tetrazole rings forming 1-D chains. (b) Representation of long-range interactions in Na coordination sphere.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Cyclic tetramers bridged by a pair of tetrazole rings forming 1-D chains. (b) Representation of long-range interactions in Na coordination sphere.

cln_elements.content: (a) 2-D packing diagram of compound 5 representing the connectivity of Hbte linker and Na­(I) coordination sphere. (b) Arrangement of Hbte linkers and solvent molecules in tetrahedral coordination geometry around the Na­(I) sphere.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (a) 2-D packing diagram of compound 5 representing the connectivity of Hbte linker and Na(I) coordination sphere. (b) Arrangement of Hbte linkers and solvent molecules in tetrahedral coordination geometry around the Na(I) sphere.

cln_elements.content: (a) Projection of 2D sheet architecture of compound 6 along the ab plane. (b) Representation of coordination and supramolecular interactions in the Na coordination sphere.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Projection of 2D sheet architecture of compound 6 along the ab plane. (b) Representation of coordination and supramolecular interactions in the Na coordination sphere.
